awards.title: 3rd prize Raak Award Immersive Journalism and the Engaged Public
2e Prijs SIA-Raak Award voor onderzoeksproject Every Picture Tells a Story
awards.description: Onderzoek naar het productieproces van visualisaties en mogelijkheden voor interdisciplinaire samenwerkingsverbanden. Volgens de jury: "De medewerkers van deze onderzoeksgroep zijn in staat creatieve bedrijven aan zich te binden en direct toepasbare instrumenten te ontwikkelen die de beroepsgroep omarmt. Een doelgericht inspirerend samenwerkingsverband dat nieuwe kennis op een natuurlijke manier met elkaar deelt en vooral toegankelijk maakt. Deze interactie met de praktijk leidt tot slimme communicatie-instrumenten gericht op het overdragen van complexe informatie."

projects.title: The informed citizen in local communities: A user-centered study on how citizens value local journalism
projects.description:
In this study, we build a conceptualization of the news experience in the context of local communities, and we wonder how people make sense of the world they live in from a local perspective. By focusing on the experiential qualities of what it means to be informed, we position our study in the growing body of literature on the immediate and lived experience of news use. This understanding of the public goes beyond understanding audience metrics or setting out surveys to find out what type of news they prefer . Only recently, Swart and colleagues argued for a more radical audience turn in journalism studies (Swart et al., 2022) in which the focus should not be as what counts as news, but what is experienced as informative. Moreover, the audience should be positioned as active agents. 
In this study, we take this user-centered approach at the level of local communities to understand how people are informed about the place where they live. Our starting point is not to define what journalism is, but to take a bottom-up approach to have the audience define what local news or information is to them. We selected eight different municipalities in the Netherlands, ranging in the population of the municipality (rural area, small towns, midsize towns, and large cities) and the number of local media that is offered (including local broadcasters, newspapers and hyperlocals). For each municipality we conducted two focus groups with citizens that are actively involved in the place they live, for example through voluntary work, organizing activities in the neighborhood to tradesmen working in the municipality. Prior to the focus groups we asked the participants to make pictures of information sources that are relevant to them.

contributors.headline: Professor Applied Sciences Journalism, Journalismlab, University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)

projects.title: Google as Journalists’ Invisible Research Assistant? The Impact of Algorithmically-Driven Search Results in Journalistic Information
projects.description: Algorithms play an increasingly important role in the information-gathering process of journalists, from selecting sources, to analyzing large data sets, and assisting in fact-checking activities. One could even say that algorithms play a crucial role in every step of the journalistic research process, merely due to the fact that journalists use search engines daily. Existing research indicates that journalists are hardly aware of algorithms at stake when using search engines. Yet, there is only little knowledge on the causality of algorithmic curation news production processes. This paper analyzes the possible influence Google has on online journalists when consulting, selecting, and evaluating sources through this search engine. We conducted a rare experiment on site with 73 working journalists within newsrooms in the Netherlands. Each participant conducted two research assignments. We find that all participating journalists, without exception, started their research with Google when following an assignment of searching and consulting sources for a story. The data also shows that these journalists mainly remain on the first page results of Google. Secondly, our analysis shows that journalists consult the sources that are offered on the first page result. When more legacy media were shown, then journalists chose more legacy media, and the other way around. Against expectations, however, we found that algorithmic logic had no significant effects on perceptions of suitability and trustworthiness of a source.

contributors.headline: Professor Applied Sciences Journalism, Journalismlab, University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)

projects.title: Lokaal online nieuws in Nederland: de opmars van de hyperlocal, gebrekkige participatie
projects.description:
Lokaal nieuws is online ruimschoots te vinden in Nederland: op websites van dagbladen, huis-aan-huisbladen, betaalde nieuwsbladen, en van regionale – en lokale omroepen. Daarnaast zijn er ‘hyperlocals’, websites met lokaal nieuws die niet verbonden zijn met een ander (offline) medium. Die laatste categorie is sterk in opkomst. We vinden meer dan één hyperlocal per gemeente en dat is fors meer dan bij een inventarisatie een aantal jaren geleden. De hyperlocal is nu de meest voorkomende lokale mediavorm. Daarna komen de websites van huis-aan-huisbladen, een sector die de afgelopen jaren fors is ingekrompen maar nog steeds in elke gemeente ook online aanwezig is, vaak ook met meer dan één titel. In elke gemeente zouden inwoners nieuws over hun woonplaats op de website van de regionale omroep kunnen vinden terwijl ook een dagbladsite vrijwel overal beschikbaar is. In zo’n 80 procent van de gemeenten heeft de lokale omroep ook een nieuwssite.

Lokaal betekent niet alleen nieuws brengen over een specifiek geografisch gebied, de ambitie van lokale media gaat verder dan dat, ze willen onderdeel uitmaken van de gemeenschap, mensen verbinden en een platform voor discussie en participatie zijn. Dat zou zich kunnen manifesteren in reacties, discussies, acties van en voor inwoners en in het algemeen in een open houding ten opzichte van bijdragen en suggesties van inwoners. Dat blijkt in de praktijk niet overal uit de verf te komen, reacties zijn veelal niet welkom (behalve op Facebook), contact wordt zo nu en dan afgeschermd en een bloeiend discussieplatform over lokale zaken is een zeldzaamheid. Ook lokale media zijn vooral geïnteresseerd in ‘zenden’.

projects.title: National Platform for Applied Sciences
projects.description: Applied Sciences generate valuable knowledge and products for use in professional practice and education. Increasing the visibility of all this information would allow the knowledge and products to reach even more people than they do now. We are developing the National Platform for Applied Sciences to help make this possible.

projects.title: News avoidance and its effect on the informed citizen in a democratic society
projects.description: How the public navigates through the widespread news landscape, and why they choose whether or not to consume something, is important to understand the changing role of news media when informing citizens. The purpose of this PhD research is to gain concrete insights into new avoiders, their motivations and how they are informed.

projects.title: Online verification
projects.description:
A research project on online verification of journalists with researchers from the University of Amsterdam and the University of Vienna. 

In an increasingly pressured newsroom environment, journalists working in newsrooms and as freelancers are struggling in finding and selecting trusted sources online. This study will directly observe how journalists select and verify online sources. A mixed-method was used. First, we conduct a randomized lab experimental design with single factor (verification request vs. no verification request) with a group of graduate journalism students (N=60) in the Netherlands. Here, we directly recorded how journalism students performed an online search activity in preparation for the production of a news item. A post-test survey asked participants on their research and verification strategies, and the resulting report is also content-analysed. 
-Presentations at academic conferences: 
Kruikemeier, S., de Haan, Y., Lecheler, S. (2017). Thank Google! Journalistic sourcing behavior online. Presentatie op ECREA Journalism Studies. Odense, Denemarken, 23 maart, 2017

profile_positions.company: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)
profile_positions.title: Member Ethical Board Applied Research

profile_positions.description:
Leading a research centre doing research on journalism in transition. 
The centre focuses on issues within the changing journalism profession in a digital landscape, questioning the news work, the ways stories are being told and the effect this has on the public. 

The research group Journalism in Digital Transition, also known as JournalismLab, is connected to the School of Journalism in Utrecht and does research on the impact of digitalization on journalism practice and education. JournalismLab carries out research in three areas: journalistic storytelling, research and education. The research always consists of scientific methods, a connection to the journalism practice and to education.

Research areas
1. Journalistic storytelling: the research group studies how journalistic organizations produce new forms of storytelling and their economic and social consequences.
2. Journalistic research: delving into changing research practices. What are the consequences of the online world for the selection and verification of news? How do journalists deal with the everyday pressure of velocity and credibility?
3. Journalism education: exploring new skills and teaching methods for journalism education.
profile_positions.title: Professor Applied Sciences Journalism in Digital Transition (Lector)
Advisory Council Member future local journalism Utrecht

company.name: Dutch Press Council (Raad voor de Journalistiek)

profile_positions.company: Dutch Press Council (Raad voor de Journalistiek)
profile_positions.description:
The Dutch Press Council has the task  to evaluate complaints against violations of good journalistic practice.
As a member, together with an interdisciplinary team of journalists, media experts and members  of the judiciary we judge complaints that come in.
profile_positions.title: Member Dutch Press Council

company.name: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)

profile_positions.company: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)
profile_positions.description:
As a project manager within the School of Journalism I am responsible for the development and implementation of a new 4-year Bachelor program, focusing on 21st century skills, interdisciplinary teamwork and innovative teaching methods in a team of 30 teachers. 
This includes developing new curriculum frameworks, supervising in writing teaching guides, professionalizing and coaching teachers in new teaching methods, advising management in human resources and talent & development.
I have provided several schools with advice on education innovation in the journalism sector including the Dublin University of Technology, University of Applied Sciences in Tilburg and Institute Pratique du Journalisme Paris-Dauphine.
profile_positions.title: Project Leader

profile_positions.company: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)
profile_positions.description:
As a senior researcher I am responsible for several research projects within the research group 'Crossmedia Journalism', publish research in academic peer-reviewed journals, collaborate with a range of media organizations and international universities in  larger research consortia and provide lecturers and presentations for media and government organizations and at international academic and professional conferences. Moreover, I supervise researchers in their research projects. 

Current research projects: 
- Media accountability and transparency within news media
- The consumption and production of new visualizations
- The use of immersive journalism and the effects on news knowledge
- New forms of media education in an interdisciplinary environment 
- Online sourcing behavior and verification
profile_positions.title: Senior Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Yearly, I provide a 3 month course at the Erasmus Mundus Master Journalism, Media and Globalisation, a interdisciplinary master program in collaboration with the University of Hamburg, City University London, University of Swansea and University of Amsterdam. 
This course takes an interdisciplinary academic perspective and studies different viewpoints in journalism studies, media policy, economics and entrepreneurship for students to work on their own start-up project that answer questions in journalism.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer Erasmus Mundus Journalism course

profile_positions.description:
As lecturer and education developer I developed and taught several BA and MA courses including: 
- qualitative research methods 
- media policy
- journalism and technology 
- supervision of MA thesis
profile_positions.title: Lecturer and education developer BA & MA courses

profile_positions.description: Pressures from politicians and the public have led to greater demands for media accountability. Moreover, the growing structural changes in the media landscape have also challenged existing notions of how media should relate to and be responsive to the public. By means of an in-depth multiple case study focused on three leading media organizations, this dissertation looks into how Dutch news media are responding to the increasing pressures in terms of accountability and responsiveness.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate
